rows.title: Praise yourself

transcript.eng:
Self-praise can be really helpful, especially when we have difficult days. 

Think of your week and finish the following phrase: “This week, I am proud of myself for …” It can be anything, not just things about being a parent!

Think of one thing you did well today. Now wrap your arms around yourself and give yourself a big HUG!

rows.transcript:
Self-praise can be really helpful, especially when we have difficult days. 

Think of your week and finish the following phrase: “This week, I am proud of myself for …” It can be anything, not just things about being a parent!

Think of one thing you did well today. Now wrap your arms around yourself and give yourself a big HUG!

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Fantastic! And well done for investing in yourself and your family – you have accomplished a lot.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Sorry that you are not having a great day. Well done for trying to figure everything out. @global.app_name is here to help.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Being a parent can be challenging. Take a deep breath and recognise all you have done for your family – you deserve praise!

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Being a parent can be stressful. Take a deep breath and recognise all the great things you have done for your family.

quiz_1_feedback_5.eng: Taking care of your family can make you tired. Take a deep breath and praise yourself for all the great things you have done for your family.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Fantastic! And well done for investing in yourself and your family – you have accomplished a lot.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Sorry that you are not having a great day. Well done for trying to figure everything out. @global.app_name is here to help.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Being a parent can be challenging. Take a deep breath and recognise all you have done for your family – you deserve praise!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Being a parent can be stressful. Take a deep breath and recognise all the great things you have done for your family.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_5: Taking care of your family can make you tired. Take a deep breath and praise yourself for all the great things you have done for your family.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's lesson is about creating structure for our children.

Rules and routines help children understand what is expected from them, be responsible, and stay safe. 

Children are more likely to follow rules if you create them TOGETHER.

Creating daily routines (around for example meals, school and bedtime) will help your child feel safe, secure, and calm.

media_title.eng: How will it help you and your family?

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Does anybody else find getting their children ready for school or bed stressful?

Guess what? Rules can help! Having clear rules and routines actually helps children know what is expected of them, which helps reduce the struggles of the more stressful moments in the day.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's lesson is about creating structure for our children.

Rules and routines help children understand what is expected from them, be responsible, and stay safe. 

Children are more likely to follow rules if you create them TOGETHER.

Creating daily routines (around for example meals, school and bedtime) will help your child feel safe, secure, and calm.
rows.media_title: How will it help you and your family?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

Does anybody else find getting their children ready for school or bed stressful?

Guess what? Rules can help! Having clear rules and routines actually helps children know what is expected of them, which helps reduce the struggles of the more stressful moments in the day.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s look at an example together. @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name is spending too much time playing games on the phone or tablet before her homework is finished. @data.characters.f1_father.name helps her create a family rule about this:

character_1_text.eng: Can I use your phone to play games?

character_2_text.eng: Sure! But let’s set some household rules for using gadgets together.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s look at an example together. @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name is spending too much time playing games on the phone or tablet before her homework is finished. @data.characters.f1_father.name helps her create a family rule about this:
rows.character_1_text: Can I use your phone to play games?
rows.character_2_text: Sure! But let’s set some household rules for using gadgets together.

character_1_text.eng: What do you think would be a fair rule?

character_2_text.eng: Hmmm…well, maybe I can use the tablet as much as I want, but only after I do my homework?

rows.character_1_text: What do you think would be a fair rule?
rows.character_2_text: Hmmm…well, maybe I can use the tablet as much as I want, but only after I do my homework?

character_1_text.eng: I like that idea, but let’s limit it to 30 minutes per day so that you have time for other fun and relaxing things too. How does that sound?

character_3_text.eng: I’ll set a timer to let us know when you have 5 minutes left.

rows.character_1_text: I like that idea, but let’s limit it to 30 minutes per day so that you have time for other fun and relaxing things too. How does that sound?
rows.character_3_text: I’ll set a timer to let us know when you have 5 minutes left.

character_1_text.eng: Can I create my own account for pictures and videos, Dad? Maha has an instagram account.

character_2_text.eng: Not just yet, @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name. Social media is for older kids. We'll wait until you're a bit older. But we can post pictures on my account together if you want.

rows.character_1_text: Can I create my own account for pictures and videos, Dad? Maha has an instagram account.
rows.character_2_text: Not just yet, @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name. Social media is for older kids. We'll wait until you're a bit older. But we can post pictures on my account together if you want.

character_1_text.eng: And remember, never click on a pop-up window or picture if it appears. Also, if anything ever upsets you, let us know right away. We're here to keep you safe!

rows.character_1_text: And remember, never click on a pop-up window or picture if it appears. Also, if anything ever upsets you, let us know right away. We're here to keep you safe!

character_1_text.eng: Thank you for doing your homework before using the tablet, @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name. Last night you mentioned that your maths tests have become easier for you! I am proud of you! We can increase your time to an hour each day… as long as you still do your homework first!

rows.character_1_text: Thank you for doing your homework before using the tablet, @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name. Last night you mentioned that your maths tests have become easier for you! I am proud of you! We can increase your time to an hour each day… as long as you still do your homework first!

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s reflect on how @data.characters.f1_father.name and @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name created a rule together.

quiz_1_question.eng: Why does @data.characters.f1_father.name ask @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name for her ideas on what the household rule should be?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Not quite. When you make rules together with your child, the rules will work better because your child will feel involved.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: To make it more likely that she follows the rule.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Correct. When you make rules together with your child, the rules will work better.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: Because @data.characters.f1_father.name is not sure how to make the rule himself.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Actually it’s to make @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name feel that her ideas are valued.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: To make sure she feels the rule is fair and realistic

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Correct. When you make rules together with your child, the rules will work better.

quiz_2_question.eng: How does @data.characters.f1_father.name make sure that @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name is safe online?

quiz_2_option_1_text.eng: A) He creates household rules around gadget use. He praises her.

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng:
If you chose A, D, or E, you are correct! 

The father 
✅ sets a household rule to limit gadget use to 30 minutes a day
✅ Asks his daughter to wait until she's older for a social media account
✅ Advises against clicking on pop-ups
✅Encourages his daughter to come talk to him if anything upsets her online.

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng:
B) He allowed his daughter to create a social media account. 
He tells her she doesn’t have to follow the rule anymore.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: Try again! Letting a child have a social media account too soon can be tricky. Waiting until they’re older helps make sure they’re ready and know how to use it safely and responsibly.

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: C) He allowed his daughter to use the mobile phone only after completing her schoolwork

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: Try again! Letting your child use the mobile phone after schoolwork is a smart move to teach responsibility. But you need to also set rules on screen time to keep things balanced and ensure they’re enjoying other activities too!

quiz_2_option_4_text.eng: D) He told his daughter to avoid clicking on pop-ups or strange pictures

quiz_2_feedback_4.eng:
If you chose A, D, or E, you are correct! 

The father 
✅ sets a household rule to limit gadget use to 30 minutes a day
✅ Asks his daughter to wait until she's older for a social media account
✅ Advises against clicking on pop-ups
✅Encourages his daughter to come talk to him if anything upsets her online.

quiz_2_option_5_text.eng: E) He told her daughter to come to him if anything upsets them

✅ Advises against clicking on pop-ups
✅Encourages his daughter to come talk to him if anything upsets her online.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s look at another family. They have set up a routine around bedtime that is working really well!

character_1_text.eng: I am so happy to see you playing quietly with your building blocks, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. In 5 minutes, it will be time to get ready for bed. When you are ready for bed, we can read a story together.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s look at another family. They have set up a routine around bedtime that is working really well!
rows.character_1_text: I am so happy to see you playing quietly with your building blocks, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. In 5 minutes, it will be time to get ready for bed. When you are ready for bed, we can read a story together.

character_1_text.eng: Time to get ready for bed, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. First, let’s get you nice and clean with a bath.

rows.character_1_text: Time to get ready for bed, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. First, let’s get you nice and clean with a bath.

character_1_text.eng: You were so well-behaved in the bath, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. Now it is time to put your pyjamas on.

rows.character_1_text: You were so well-behaved in the bath, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. Now it is time to put your pyjamas on.

character_1_text.eng: Well done for putting on your pyjamas by yourself, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name! Now let’s brush your teeth. Make sure you get the ones in the back of your mouth too!

rows.character_1_text: Well done for putting on your pyjamas by yourself, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name! Now let’s brush your teeth. Make sure you get the ones in the back of your mouth too!

character_1_text.eng: You did so well getting ready for bed! Now, we have time to read a story. Which book would you like to read?

character_2_text.eng: Yay! Can you read me the story about the lion?

rows.character_1_text: You did so well getting ready for bed! Now, we have time to read a story. Which book would you like to read?
rows.character_2_text: Yay! Can you read me the story about the lion?

character_1_text.eng: The end….” I’m glad you chose that story for us to read, it’s one of my favourites! Goodnight, my dear. I love you very much.

rows.character_1_text: The end….” I’m glad you chose that story for us to read, it’s one of my favourites! Goodnight, my dear. I love you very much.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s think about what made this routine work well so we can all have peaceful bedtimes in our families.

quiz_1_question.eng: How often do you think @data.characters.f3_mother.name and @data.characters.f3_son_4.name follow this routine?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Try again. If @data.characters.f3_mother.name and @data.characters.f3_son_4.name only do these steps once a week, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name would not be able to remember and follow the routine as well as she does here.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Try again. Following these steps only a few times a week may confuse @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, and she may struggle to follow the routine as well as she does here.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng:
Exactly. Being consistent with a routine – especially at the end of the day when everyone is tired – makes activities easier to follow for children. 

With a bit of practice, bedtime can become a happy time of connecting with your child!

quiz_2_question.eng: What does @data.characters.f3_mother.name do to help @data.characters.f3_son_4.name follow this routine?

quiz_2_option_1_text.eng: She connects with @data.characters.f3_son_4.name before giving instructions

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Yes, connecting properly helps encourage @data.characters.f3_son_4.name to follow the routine successfully.

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng: She warns him that there will be consequences if he doesn’t follow the routine.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: No, @data.characters.f3_mother.name doesn’t have to use consequences but she does promise a reward, which helped @data.characters.f3_son_4.name to follow the routine successfully.

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: She gives @data.characters.f3_son_4.name a transition warning for each step of the routine.

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: Yes, knowing which step comes next helps @data.characters.f3_son_4.name to follow the routine successfully.

quiz_2_feedback_4.eng: Not quite. What’s important about the instructions is that she gives them one at a time. This means @data.characters.f3_son_4.name doesn’t get confused and helps him to follow the routine successfully.

quiz_2_option_5_text.eng: She lets @data.characters.f3_son_4.name do the routine by herself.

quiz_2_feedback_5.eng: Not quite, but she does praise him after each step. This will help @data.characters.f3_son_4.name to remember how to follow the routine successfully next time.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Try again. If @data.characters.f3_mother.name and @data.characters.f3_son_4.name only do these steps once a week, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name would not be able to remember and follow the routine as well as she does here.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Try again. Following these steps only a few times a week may confuse @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, and she may struggle to follow the routine as well as she does here.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3:
Exactly. Being consistent with a routine – especially at the end of the day when everyone is tired – makes activities easier to follow for children. 

With a bit of practice, bedtime can become a happy time of connecting with your child!

rows.quiz_2_feedback_2: No, @data.characters.f3_mother.name doesn’t have to use consequences but she does promise a reward, which helped @data.characters.f3_son_4.name to follow the routine successfully.

text_1_facilitator.eng: These four tips will help you create rules and routines to bring more structure and peace in your home:

section_1_text.eng: When you involve your child in making rules they are more likely to follow them. One rule at a time is easiest.

section_1_extra_text.eng:
Plan rules WITH your child. Discuss the reasons for the rule and ask about their ideas.

Older children can share their own ideas of what they think the rule should be and you can agree together. They will feel appreciated and heard.

section_2_text.eng:
Consider your child’s age and developmental level when creating rules and routines. They have to be able to do what is expected of them.

Remember: Only introduce one new rule or routine at a time – you can add another one later.

section_2_extra_text.eng: Make rules and routines realistic for what your child can actually do and specific so there is no misunderstanding. Don’t say “ “clean up” but “pick up all of your building blocks”.

section_3_text.eng:
Make sure your child follows the rules and routines daily.

That way, your child knows what to expect and this will help them to feel secure. They will learn to be more independent and responsible.

section_3_extra_text.eng: Activities become easier when children learn and get used to a routine.

rows.text_1_facilitator: These four tips will help you create rules and routines to bring more structure and peace in your home:
rows.section_1_text: When you involve your child in making rules they are more likely to follow them. One rule at a time is easiest.
rows.section_1_extra_text:
Plan rules WITH your child. Discuss the reasons for the rule and ask about their ideas.

Older children can share their own ideas of what they think the rule should be and you can agree together. They will feel appreciated and heard.
rows.section_2_text:
Consider your child’s age and developmental level when creating rules and routines. They have to be able to do what is expected of them.

Remember: Only introduce one new rule or routine at a time – you can add another one later.
rows.section_2_extra_text: Make rules and routines realistic for what your child can actually do and specific so there is no misunderstanding. Don’t say “ “clean up” but “pick up all of your building blocks”.
rows.section_3_text:
Make sure your child follows the rules and routines daily.

That way, your child knows what to expect and this will help them to feel secure. They will learn to be more independent and responsible.
rows.section_3_extra_text: Activities become easier when children learn and get used to a routine.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are some tips on rules and routines that will help you keep your child safe online:

section_1_text.eng: Take control of your devices to keep them safe for your children.

section_1_extra_text.eng:
Set up [parental controls](https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/) on your gadgets 

Turn on [SafeSearch](https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/entertainment-search-engines/) on your browser 

Set up strict [privacy settings](https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/social-media/) on online apps and games 

Cover webcams when not in use

section_2_text.eng:
Involve your child in creating family tech rules. 

Create device-free spaces and times in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping)

section_2_extra_text.eng: Tell your child that if they experience something online that makes them feel upset, uncomfortable, or scared, they can talk to you and you will not get mad or punish them.

section_3_text.eng:
Spending time with your child online helps you understand their digital world and build a stronger connection. 

Talking regularly about what your child sees online can help build trust and keep communication open.
Use simple language they understand!

section_3_extra_text.eng:
Explore websites, social media, games, and apps together 

[Common Sense Media](https://www.commonsensemedia.org/app-reviews)
has great advice for apps,
games and entertainment for
different ages.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s come up with some ideas for rules and routines in your home.

text_2.eng: Here are some of the rules and routines that other families created.

quiz_1_question.eng: Would you like to try one of these rules with your child?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: Your child can play after finishing homework.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: All family members eat dinner together.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: Say ‘please’ when you ask someone to help you with something.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: Your child packs away the toys they played with during the day before bedtime

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.

quiz_2_question.eng: In which of these areas would you like to create routines with your child?

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child. Remember bedtime routines work best when they are predictable and calm!

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child. Remember to use positive instructions when setting up this routine.

quiz_2_feedback_4.eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child. Remember that mealtime routines work best when they are predictable.

quiz_2_feedback_5.eng: Wonderful! Remember to praise for following through on chore routines! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child.

quiz_2_feedback_6.eng: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: This is a great rule! Discuss it with your child and family, or come up with a different rule that will help you at home.
rows.quiz_1_question: Would you like to try one of these rules with your child?
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: Your child can play after finishing homework.
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: All family members eat dinner together.
rows.quiz_1_option_3_text: Say ‘please’ when you ask someone to help you with something.
rows.quiz_1_option_4_text: Your child packs away the toys they played with during the day before bedtime
rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s come up with some ideas for rules and routines in your home.
rows.quiz_2_question: In which of these areas would you like to create routines with your child?
rows.quiz_2_feedback_1: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_2: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child. Remember bedtime routines work best when they are predictable and calm!
rows.quiz_2_feedback_3: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child. Remember to use positive instructions when setting up this routine.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_4: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child. Remember that mealtime routines work best when they are predictable.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_5: Wonderful! Remember to praise for following through on chore routines! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child.
rows.text_2: Here are some of the rules and routines that other families created.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_6: Wonderful! Give it a try and see how it will change your relationship with your child.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Your home activity is to set *one* rule and *one* routine with your child. 

Remember to be realistic and consistent, and praise your child for following each rule or routine!

quiz_1_question.eng: Can you set one routine and one rule with your child?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That's great! I hope it makes your home feel easier to manage for everyone.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That's okay. Setting rules is hard and including children can feel uncomfortable, especially if you’re not used to it. Keep trying until you find a way that works for you and your children. It will be worth it!

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That's great! I hope it makes your home feel easier to manage for everyone.

Your home activity is to set *one* rule and *one* routine with your child. 

Remember to be realistic and consistent, and praise your child for following each rule or routine!
